abstract.text: The most recent results of the top-quark mass measurements with the ATLAS detector using data collected from proton-proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider are presented.
Although several decay modes of the top-quark pairs have been used in ATLAS for top-quark mass measurements, only the latest results are presented (single lepton and dilepton channels).
The top-quark pole mass from the tt cross-section measurement in the dilepton channel and the top-antitop quark mass difference measurement in the single-lepton channel are also shown.
The systematic uncertainties associated to these measurements are discussed in some detail.

body_text.text: Introduction
The top quark is the heaviest elementary particle in the Standard Model and its mass is a fundamental parameter in quantum chromodynamics.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Its value must be determined experimentally and its precise measurement has a large impact in the computation of electroweak corrections.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The ATLAS detector [1] is a general purpose detector located at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) [2].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Over the last years, the ATLAS Collaboration has measured the top-quark mass with increasing precision, with the following most recent analyses:
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: • Top-quark mass measurement in the tt single lepton channel [3];
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: • Top-quark mass measurement in the tt dilepton channel [4];
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: • Top-quark pole mass from the tt cross-section measurement in the dilepton channel [5];
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: • Top-antitop mass difference in the tt single lepton channel [6].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Almost all the analyses use the template method to extract the variable of interest from data, where the templates are built with the help of Monte-Carlo simulations.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Top-quark mass measurement in the tt single lepton channel
The analysis [3] is performed using data at a centreof-mass energy of √ s = 7 TeV, which amounts to an integrated luminosity of 4.7 fb −1 .
body_text.section: Top-quark mass measurement in the tt single lepton channel

body_text.text: A three-dimensional template technique is used, where the m reco top , the jet scale factor (JSF) and the b-jet scale factor (bJSF) are measured simultaneously by fitting the distribution of three observables reconstructed using a kinematic likelihood fit: the top-quark mass, the W-boson mass and the ratio between the average transverse momentum of the b-tagged jets and the average transverse momentum of the two jets of the W-boson hadronic decay, R reco b (see Figure 1).
body_text.section: Top-quark mass measurement in the tt single lepton channel

body_text.text: The reconstructed top-quark mass is expected to be sensitive to the top-quark mass, the JSF and the bJSF, while the reconstructed W-boson mass is expected to only depend on the JSF.
body_text.section: Top-quark mass measurement in the tt single lepton channel

body_text.text: Finally, the reconstructed R lb is expected to depend on the bJSF and the top-quark mass.

body_text.section: Top-quark mass measurement in the tt single lepton channel

body_text.text: By comparing a two-dimensional template analysis (where the b-jet energy scale is fixed) to the threedimensional template analysis (where the b-jet energy scale is allowed to vary), it is shown that the three-dimensional template technique significantly reduces the b-jet energy scale uncertainty from 0.92 GeV to 0.08 GeV and the hadronization uncertainty from 1.30 GeV to 0.27 GeV.

body_text.text: There is a drawback, however, since the b-tagging efficiency and mistag rate uncertainty increases from 0.17 GeV to 0.81 GeV.

body_text.text: Top-quark mass measurement in the tt dilepton channel
The dilepton channel does not allow a direct mass reconstruction, but has the advantage that it offers a very clean signal and a very good signal-to-background ratio.
body_text.section: Top-quark mass measurement in the tt dilepton channel

body_text.text: The analysis [4] is performed using 4.7 fb −1 of 7 TeV data.
body_text.section: Top-quark mass measurement in the tt dilepton channel

body_text.text: The template method is used to measure the topquark mass using the m b variable, defined as the average invariant mass of the two lepton-b-jet systems in the dileptonic channel.

body_text.text: Since the correct pairing between the two leptons and the two b-jets is not known, the values of m b for both combinations are computed and the smallest value is taken.

body_text.text: Top-quark pole mass from the tt cross-section measurement in the dilepton channel

The ATLAS collaboration has performed a tt crosssection measurement in the dilepton channel using With the top-quark mass measurements reaching precisions of the order 1 GeV, one should remember that the values of these reconstructed top-quark masses are different from the value of the top-quark pole mass.
body_text.section: Top-quark pole mass from the tt cross-section measurement in the dilepton channel

body_text.text: This difference has been estimated to be of the order of 1 GeV [7].
body_text.section: Top-quark pole mass from the tt cross-section measurement in the dilepton channel

body_text.text: The top-quark pole mass, i.e., the mass of the top quark as a free particle, can be computed from the tt cross section.
body_text.section: Top-quark pole mass from the tt cross-section measurement in the dilepton channel

body_text.text: The idea is to exploit the strong dependence of the tt cross section on the top-quark pole mass.
body_text.section: Top-quark pole mass from the tt cross-section measurement in the dilepton channel

body_text.text: This dependence is obtained for both centre-of-mass energies using different parton density function (PDF) models, as shown in Figure 4.
body_text.section: Top-quark pole mass from the tt cross-section measurement in the dilepton channel

body_text.text: Notice that the measured cross section does not depend on the assumed input Monte-Carlo top-quark mass, ensuring that the method used to measure the tt cross section is independent from the value of the top-quark pole mass.

body_text.text: This requirement is important in order to extract the top-quark pole mass from the measured value of the tt cross section.

body_text.text: Top-antitop mass difference in the tt single lepton channel
